metadata.titleEn: Crevasse dataset over typical ice shelves in Antarctica（2015、2016、2020）
metadata.description: We propose an algorithm for ice crack identification and detection using u-net network, which can realize the automatic detection of Antarctic ice cracks. Based on the data of sentinel-1 EW from January  to February  every year, in order to suppress the speckle noise of SAR image, the probabilistic patch based weights (ppb) algorithm is selected for filtering, and then representative samples are selected and input into the u-net network for model training, and the ice cracks are predicted according to the trained model. Taking five typical ice shelves（Amery、Fimbul、Nickerson、Shackleton、Thwaiters) in Antarctica as an example, the average accuracy of classification results can reach 94.5%, of which the local accuracy of fissure area can reach 78.6%, and the recall rate is 89.4%.
metadata.instructions: Crevasses data is stored in shpfile format, and the file is named ice shelf name + year.Shp. All shpfile files in the dataset can be opened directly with arcgis/qgis and other software.

background: Crevasses have developed on almost all glaciers and ice shelves and are the direct result of glacier movement, reflecting the characteristics of glacier development and stresses. The crevasses contribute to the glacier mass balance through impacting the processes of meltwater transportation on the ice surface. Additionally, when sufficient surface meltwater infuses into crevasses, hydrofracturing may be induced, resulting in ice shelf instability; thus, crevasses are essential factors for assessing the stability of glaciers and ice shelves. Antarctic scientific research expeditions are also closely associated with crevasses because the rapid appearance of crevasses may herald the disintegration of the ice shelf and pose a serious safety hazard to field researchers. The orientation and distribution of crevasses can be used to distinguish the ice flow regimes and provide qualitative insight into trends in ice flow. Therefore, crevasses are critical not only for investigating the ice shelves’ stability as well as glacier dynamics but also for providing important safety guidance for glaciological field campaigns.
research objective: In this study, we propose an automated crevasse extraction framework based on Sentinel-1 SAR imagery and an improved U-Net network.
challenges: However, in some scenes, the recall rate was relatively lower due to the quality of the SAR image, terrain surrounding the crevasses, and observation geometry.
methods: This study used the LabelMe tool to manually make labels and finally convert the labels into json format. A modified U-Net network was implemented in this study for pixel-level crevasse identification. The modified U-Net network in this study (1) used a deconvolution layer (up-sampling 2 × 2) to replace the fully connected layer because the fully connected layer not only loses location information but also adds additional parameters. In addition, in such a deep neural network, we added the Batch Normalization (BN) layer before the input of each layer of the network to solve the problem of imbalanced data distribution and regularize the model. To improve the classification accuracy and avoid the phenomenon of gradient disappearance or gradient explosion in the training process, this study added skip connections after the convolutional layer. The model was compiled using the “binary cross-entropy” loss function, Adaptive Moment Estimation (Adam) optimizer, and an initial learning rate of 0.001. Finally, the model converged after 75 epochs.
dataset: The spatial distribution of crevasses on Antarctic ice shelves in 2020 was mapped with a spatial resolution of ~40 m, and the characteristics of crevasses on the Nickerson Ice Shelf, Jelbart Ice Shelf, Amery Ice Shelf, Thwaites Glacier, and Shackleton Ice Shelf were analyzed.
findings: The results indicated the extraction accuracy of our method was 84.2% and the F1 score was 72.5%. The crevasses on different ice shelves had different characteristics in terms of length, density, type, and spatial pattern, implying the different stress structures of ice shelves. The Thwaites Glacier and the Nickerson Ice Shelf in the West Antarctica Ice Sheet (WAIS) had shorter ice crevasses, whereas the lengths of ice crevasses on the Jelbart Ice Shelf and the Amery Ice Shelf in the East Antarctica Ice Sheet (EAIS) were relatively long. Nevertheless, there are more closely spaced crevasses on the ice shelf in WAIS compared to that in the EAIS. For the distribution of crevasse types, the Nickerson Ice Shelf and the Shackleton Ice Shelf had various forms of crevasses. There were mainly transverse crevasses developed on the Jelbart Ice Shelf and the Amery Ice Shelf. This study provides a helpful reference and guidance for automated crevasse extraction.

Definition.Question: What is the U-Net network in the context of crevasse identification on Antarctic ice shelves?
Definition.Answer: The U-Net network, in this context, refers to a deep learning architecture used for pixel-level crevasse identification. It is modified by using a deconvolution layer to replace the fully connected layer to preserve location information and reduce parameters. Batch Normalization layers are added to address imbalanced data distribution, and skip connections are included to prevent gradient issues during training.

Definition.Question: What is the Probabilistic Patch-Based Weights (PPB) algorithm in relation to SAR image filtering?
Definition.Answer: The Probabilistic Patch-Based Weights (PPB) algorithm is a method used to filter SAR images to suppress speckle noise. It is applied to the Sentinel-1 SAR imagery to improve the quality of the images before they are used in the U-Net network for crevasse detection.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of the Probabilistic Patch-Based Weights (PPB) algorithm for noise reduction in SAR images compare to other noise reduction methods in terms of accuracy and recall rate for crevasse detection on Antarctic ice shelves?
Comparison.Answer: The use of the PPB algorithm is aimed at suppressing SAR image noise, which is crucial for improving the accuracy of crevasse detection. In the described approach, the average accuracy achieved was 94.5%, with a recall rate of 89.4% in certain scenes. While other noise reduction methods weren't explicitly compared in the field, the PPB algorithm was chosen specifically to address the coherent speckle noise in the SAR images, which can significantly impact the detection process.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in crevasse characteristics observed between the West Antarctica Ice Sheet (WAIS) and the East Antarctica Ice Sheet (EAIS) using the automated crevasse extraction framework?
Comparison.Answer: The automated crevasse extraction framework revealed that crevasses on the WAIS, such as those on the Thwaites Glacier and Nickerson Ice Shelf, were generally shorter but more closely spaced compared to those on the EAIS, such as the Jelbart and Amery Ice Shelves, which had relatively long crevasses. Additionally, the crevasse types varied, with the Nickerson and Shackleton Ice Shelves exhibiting various forms, while the Jelbart and Amery Ice Shelves mainly showed transverse crevasses.

Interpretation.Question: How can the use of U-net and SAR imagery in crevasse detection inform the development of automated methods for other glaciological features?
Interpretation.Answer: An automated crevasse extraction framework utilizing Sentinel-1 SAR imagery and an improved U-Net network can provide insights into developing similar automated methods for detecting other glaciological features by leveraging its ability to identify pixel-level details and adapt to different ice shelf characteristics.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges in SAR image quality and observation geometry might affect the reliability of large-scale crevasse datasets, and how could these be mitigated?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in SAR image quality and observation geometry can result in lower recall rates in some scenes. These challenges might be mitigated by employing advanced filtering techniques such as the Probabilistic Patch-Based Weights (PPB) algorithm to suppress noise and by refining the model to better handle variations in terrain and image quality.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the stress structures of different Antarctic ice shelves based on the characteristics of crevasses identified in a dataset?
Interpretation.Answer: The characteristics of crevasses, such as length, density, type, and spatial pattern, can imply different stress structures of ice shelves. For example, shorter crevasses on Thwaites Glacier and Nickerson Ice Shelf suggest a different stress regime compared to the longer crevasses on Jelbart and Amery Ice Shelves, while the variety of crevasse types on Nickerson and Shackleton Ice Shelves indicate diverse stress structures.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons for modifying the U-Net network in crevasse identification on Antarctic ice shelves?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The U-Net network is modified to enhance pixel-level crevasse identification accuracy by addressing issues like loss of location information, imbalanced data distribution, and avoiding gradient problems during training.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on the understanding of ice shelf stability and glacier dynamics when using automated crevasse extraction frameworks?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using automated crevasse extraction frameworks can significantly enhance the understanding of ice shelf stability and glacier dynamics. It enables large-scale, consistent, and repeatable analysis of crevasse characteristics such as length, density, type, and spatial distribution. These insights can inform assessments of stress structures, predict potential ice shelf disintegration events, and guide glaciological field campaigns.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of employing U-net network algorithms for automated crevasse detection on Antarctic ice shelves?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal of employing U-net network algorithms for automated crevasse detection is to provide an automated framework for identifying crevasses using Sentinel-1 SAR imagery. This approach aims to enhance the stability assessment of glaciers and ice shelves, as well as to offer important safety guidance for glaciological field campaigns.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to filter SAR images using the Probabilistic Patch-Based Weights (PPB) algorithm before inputting them into a U-net network?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Filtering SAR images using the Probabilistic Patch-Based Weights (PPB) algorithm is important to suppress speckle noise inherent in SAR imagery. This preprocessing step improves the image quality, which is crucial for the accurate training and performance of the U-net network in predicting crevasse locations.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind analyzing the spatial distribution and characteristics of crevasses on various Antarctic ice shelves?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives behind analyzing the spatial distribution and characteristics of crevasses on various Antarctic ice shelves include understanding the different stress structures of ice shelves, evaluating their stability, and distinguishing ice flow regimes. This analysis also provides insights into the dynamics of glaciers and contributes to safety assessments in Antarctic scientific research expeditions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the specific data preprocessing steps required before inputting Sentinel-1 SAR imagery into a U-net network for ice crevasse detection?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To preprocess Sentinel-1 SAR imagery, the Probabilistic Patch-Based Weights (PPB) algorithm is used to filter the images and suppress speckle noise. This ensures that representative samples are selected for input into the U-net network, facilitating effective model training and crevasse prediction.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the automated extraction of crevasses using satellite imagery in Antarctic research?
Enablement.Answer: An automated crevasse extraction framework based on Sentinel-1 SAR imagery and an improved U-Net network enables this process, utilizing deconvolution layers, Batch Normalization, and skip connections to improve accuracy and regularize the model.

Enablement.Question: What data filtering techniques are employed to improve the quality of SAR imagery for crevasse detection?
Enablement.Answer: The Probabilistic Patch-Based Weights (PPB) algorithm is used for filtering to suppress speckle noise in SAR images, which enhances the quality of input data for crevasse detection.

Expectation.Question: Why might different ice shelves exhibit distinct characteristics in crevasse datasets, and how does this impact data collection methods?
Expectation.Answer: Different ice shelves exhibit distinct crevasse characteristics due to varying stress structures, which can impact data collection methods by requiring tailored analysis of length, density, type, and spatial pattern to accurately capture these variations.

Judgmental.Question: How effective is the U-Net network in automating the detection of crevasses on Antarctic ice shelves, and what are the potential limitations of using such a method?
Judgmental.Answer: The U-Net network is effective in automating the detection of crevasses, achieving an average accuracy of 94.5% for classification and 78.6% for local accuracy in crevasse regions. However, potential limitations include lower recall rates due to SAR image quality, terrain surrounding the crevasses, and observation geometry.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could data collection methods be enhanced to improve the accuracy and reliability of crevasse detection on Antarctic ice shelves?
Judgmental.Answer: Data collection methods could be enhanced by improving the quality of SAR imagery, optimizing observation geometry, and employing advanced filtering techniques like Probabilistic Patch-Based Weights (PPB) to reduce noise. Additionally, incorporating more comprehensive training datasets with diverse crevasse characteristics could improve model accuracy and reliability.

The spacing and types of crevasses also differ, reflecting the different stress structures of the ice shelves.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the effectiveness of using modified U-Net networks for pixel-level crevasse identification and discuss any technological details that enhance model performance.
Request/Directive.Answer: The modified U-Net network used for pixel-level crevasse identification includes a deconvolution layer for up-sampling instead of a fully connected layer, Batch Normalization (BN) layers before each network layer input, and skip connections after convolutional layers. These modifications help maintain location information, regularize the model, balance data distribution, and prevent gradient issues during training, leading to improved classification accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please detail a dataset that provides information on the characteristics of crevasses on Antarctic ice shelves and discuss its significance for assessing ice shelf stability.
Request/Directive.Answer: A dataset maps the spatial distribution of crevasses on Antarctic ice shelves with a spatial resolution of approximately 40 meters, analyzing crevasse characteristics on Nickerson Ice Shelf, Jelbart Ice Shelf, Amery Ice Shelf, Thwaites Glacier, and Shackleton Ice Shelf. This dataset is significant for assessing ice shelf stability as it provides critical insights into the different stress structures and spatial patterns of crevasses, which are essential for evaluating ice shelf dynamics and potential stability issues.
